result.markdown: --- title: "Crime Data in Los Angeles" subtitle: "Febraury 10, 2020 to November 1, 2023" bibliography: reference.bib --- ## [Introduction]{style="color:#3eb489;"} ![Source:[@image]](LA.PNG){fig-align="center" width="80%"} The City of Los Angeles, a well-known and prosperous place in United States, attracts more people move in and settle down every year. It is common for every person to ask a question: Is the City of Los Angles a dangerous city, and what is the general distribution of crime incidents considering various factors? The safety evaluation before living in the area formally is extremely important for every [future residents]{style="color:#3eb489;"}, and the evaluation can help [policymakers]{style="color:#3eb489;"} make better policies to improve city infrastructure and protect current residents. Therefore, the data analysis of crime incidents in the City of Los Angeles provided by LAPD (Los Angeles Police Department) would be really helpful. We all know that keeping safe is always on the top. ## [Data Information]{style="color:#3eb489;"} Gaining aspirations from the experts[@Campedelli_2020; @hussain2022crime], I chose the newst crime data from Los Angeles Open Data - Public Safety-Crime Data from 2020 to Present[@Data], and it includes the information about crimes happened since Febraury 10, 2020, provided by [LAPD]{style="color:#3eb489;"} (Los Angeles Police Department). I downloaded the dataset and began to conduct the analysis on November 5, 2023, and becuase the website is updated weekly, the dataset I analyzed on my web page only contains the crime information from Febraury 10, 2020 to November 1, 2023. ::: callout-note You can choose to click the link and export the dataset using the 'Export' buttom on the web page. You can also choose to download *data.zip* from my GitHub directory. I compressed the dataset into *data.zip*, and stored it in GitHub directory for convenience. If the website accidently expires, you can get access to the dataset by visiting my GitHub directory. ::: ::: callout-important All data in the dataset was obtained from the crime paper report, so if the paper report provided inaccurate or wrong information, the dataset may be not 100% accurate. But the dataset truly reflects the content of paper report. ::: ## [Analysis]{style="color:#3eb489;"} ### Pre-Analysis ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(readr) library(lubridate) library(forcats) library(tidyverse) ``` ::: ### Data Overview First, read the data from *data.zip* file, and store it in local environment. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data <- read.csv(unz("data.zip", "Crime_Data_from_2020_to_Present_20231105.csv"), header = TRUE,sep = ",") ``` ::: Then, let's have a brief overview of this dataset. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dim(data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 829778 28 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} colnames(data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "DR_NO" "Date.Rptd" "DATE.OCC" "TIME.OCC" [5] "AREA" "AREA.NAME" "Rpt.Dist.No" "Part.1.2" [9] "Crm.Cd" "Crm.Cd.Desc" "Mocodes" "Vict.Age" [13] "Vict.Sex" "Vict.Descent" "Premis.Cd" "Premis.Desc" [17] "Weapon.Used.Cd" "Weapon.Desc" "Status" "Status.Desc" [21] "Crm.Cd.1" "Crm.Cd.2" "Crm.Cd.3" "Crm.Cd.4" [25] "LOCATION" "Cross.Street" "LAT" "LON" ``` ::: ::: This dataset has approximately 830K rows and 28 columns, containing many useful information including crime report data, number of cases, crime area/age/sex/serious level/address, etc. There are many analysis possibilities using this dataset. The detailed data dictionary is . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} for (col in 1:ncol(data)) { print(paste(colnames(data)[col], sum(is.na(data[col])))) } ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "DR_NO 0" [1] "Date.Rptd 0" [1] "DATE.OCC 0" [1] "TIME.OCC 0" [1] "AREA 0" [1] "AREA.NAME 0" [1] "Rpt.Dist.No 0" [1] "Part.1.2 0" [1] "Crm.Cd 0" [1] "Crm.Cd.Desc 0" [1] "Mocodes 0" [1] "Vict.Age 0" [1] "Vict.Sex 0" [1] "Vict.Descent 0" [1] "Premis.Cd 10" [1] "Premis.Desc 0" [1] "Weapon.Used.Cd 540459" [1] "Weapon.Desc 0" [1] "Status 0" [1] "Status.Desc 0" [1] "Crm.Cd.1 10" [1] "Crm.Cd.2 768750" [1] "Crm.Cd.3 827720" [1] "Crm.Cd.4 829717" [1] "LOCATION 0" [1] "Cross.Street 0" [1] "LAT 0" [1] "LON 0" ``` ::: ::: Some columns exist the NA values, and some character columns have empty strings without providing any useful information. Therefore, pay attention to these columns, and process the dataset using some filter functions to perform better analysis. ### Data Analysis In my analysis, I will focus on answering the question: [What are the features of victims in the City of Los Angeles?]{style="color:#3eb489;"} #### [How does the crime incidents change over time (2020-2023)?]{style="color:#3eb489;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data %>% select(Date.Rptd,Crm.Cd) %>% mutate(Date.Rptd = mdy(sub("(\\d{2}/\\d{2}/\\d{4}).*", "\\1", Date.Rptd))) %>% arrange(Date.Rptd) %>% group_by(Date.Rptd) %>% summarize(cases = n(),.groups='drop') %>% ggplot(aes(x = Date.Rptd, y = cases)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "gam", se = FALSE)+ labs( x = "Date of Crime Report", y = "Number of Cases", title = "The Number of Criminal Cases in the City of Los Angeles", subtitle = "Febraury 10, 2020 - November 1, 2023", caption = "Christine Hou", color = "Area Names" ) + theme_classic() + theme( plot.title = element_text(size=12), plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), legend.title = element_text(size=9), legend.text = element_text(size=8), axis.title = element_text(size = 9), axis.text.x = element_text(size = 8,angle = 45, hjust = 1), axis.text.y = element_text(size = 8) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](data_analysis_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=100%} ::: ::: As we can see from the plot, the criminal cases in the Los Angeles is increasing over time from 2020 to 2023. There exists the fluctuations, but the general trend is increasing. #### [Now, it is the time to know more crime statistics.]{style="color:#3eb489;"} 1. Victim Gender ::: column-margin The categories of gender and its abbreviation is here: https://data.lacity.org/Public-Safety/Crime-Data-from-2020-to-Present/2nrs-mtv8#:\~:text=crime%20incident-,Columns,-in%20this%20Dataset ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} unique(data$Vict.Sex) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "F" "M" "X" "" "H" "-" ``` ::: ::: Replace `NA` values, empty strings (""), and non-sense categories ("H","-") into unknown category ("X"). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vic_sex = data %>% mutate(Date.Rptd = mdy(sub("(\\d{2}/\\d{2}/\\d{4}).*", "\\1", Date.Rptd)), Vict.Sex = ifelse(Vict.Sex %in% c("F","M","X"),Vict.Sex, "X")) %>% arrange(Date.Rptd) %>% select(Crm.Cd, Vict.Sex, Date.Rptd) %>% group_by(Vict.Sex,Date.Rptd) %>% summarise(cases = n(),.groups = 'drop') head(vic_sex) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 3 Vict.Sex Date.Rptd cases 1 F 2020-01-01 149 2 F 2020-01-02 141 3 F 2020-01-03 141 4 F 2020-01-04 175 5 F 2020-01-05 159 6 F 2020-01-06 192 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} vic_sex %>% ggplot(aes(x = Date.Rptd, y = cases,color = Vict.Sex)) + geom_line() + theme_classic() + labs( x = "Date of Crime Report", y = "Number of Cases", title = "Victim Gender of Crime in the City of Los Angeles", subtitle = "Febraury 10, 2020 - November 1, 2023", color = "Gender", caption = "Christine Hou" ) + theme( plot.title = element_text(size=13), plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), axis.title = element_text(size = 9), axis.text = element_text(size = 8) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](data_analysis_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Generally, the male victims are more. Between 2022 and 2023, there were multiple peaks of female victims, but the number of female victims was getting lower than that of male victims again after 2023. 2. Victim Age ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vic_age = data %>% mutate(Date.Rptd = mdy(sub("(\\d{2}/\\d{2}/\\d{4}).*", "\\1", Date.Rptd)), Vict.Sex = ifelse(Vict.Sex %in% c("F","M","X"),Vict.Sex, "X"), Age = case_when(Vict.Age <= 20 ~ "0-20", Vict.Age >= 21 & Vict.Age <= 40 ~ "21-40", Vict.Age >= 41 & Vict.Age <= 60 ~ "41-60", Vict.Age >= 61 & Vict.Age <= 80 ~ "61-80", Vict.Age >= 81 & Vict.Age <= max(data$Vict.Age) ~ "80-")) %>% arrange(Date.Rptd) %>% select(Crm.Cd,Age,Date.Rptd) %>% group_by(Age, Date.Rptd) %>% summarise(cases = n(), .groups = 'drop') head(vic_age) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 3 Age Date.Rptd cases 1 0-20 2020-01-01 80 2 0-20 2020-01-02 100 3 0-20 2020-01-03 109 4 0-20 2020-01-04 123 5 0-20 2020-01-05 97 6 0-20 2020-01-06 145 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} vic_age %>% ggplot(aes(x = Age, y = cases)) + geom_boxplot() + theme_classic() + labs( x = "Age Range", y = "Number of Cases", title = "Victim Age of Crime in the City of Los Angeles", subtitle = "Febraury 10, 2020 - November 1, 2023", caption = "Christine Hou", fill = "Age Range" ) + theme( plot.title = element_text(size=12), plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), legend.title = element_text(size=9), legend.text = element_text(size=8), axis.title = element_text(size = 9), axis.text = element_text(size = 8) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](data_analysis_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Generally, people in age ranges of 0-20 and 21-40 years old have higher risk of being hurt. The age range with the highest ciminal cases report is 21-40 years old, and that with the lowest is over 80 years old. 3. Victim Race ::: column-margin The categories of race and its abbreviation is here: https://data.lacity.org/Public-Safety/Crime-Data-from-2020-to-Present/2nrs-mtv8#:\~:text=crime%20incident-,Columns,-in%20this%20Dataset ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} unique(data$Vict.Descent) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "B" "H" "X" "W" "A" "O" "" "C" "F" "K" "I" "V" "Z" "J" "P" "G" "U" "D" "S" [20] "L" "-" ``` ::: ::: Replace empty string ("") and non-sense characters ("-") into unknown category ("X"). ::: {.cell fig.asp='1.5'} ```{.r .cell-code} vic_race = data %>% mutate(Date.Rptd = mdy(sub("(\\d{2}/\\d{2}/\\d{4}).*", "\\1", Date.Rptd)), Vict.Descent = ifelse(Vict.Descent == "-"|Vict.Descent == "", "X", Vict.Descent)) %>% arrange(Date.Rptd) %>% select(Crm.Cd, Vict.Descent, Date.Rptd) %>% group_by(Vict.Descent, Date.Rptd) %>% summarise(cases = n(), .groups = "drop") head(vic_race) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 3 Vict.Descent Date.Rptd cases 1 A 2020-01-01 6 2 A 2020-01-02 14 3 A 2020-01-03 10 4 A 2020-01-04 11 5 A 2020-01-05 6 6 A 2020-01-06 15 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} vic_race %>% ggplot(aes(x = Date.Rptd, y = cases)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = 'gam',se = FALSE) + facet_wrap(Vict.Descent~.,nrow=7,scales = 'fixed') + theme_classic() + labs( x = "Date of Crime Report", y = "Number of Cases", title = "Victim Race of Crime in the City of Los Angeles", subtitle = "Febraury 10, 2020 - November 1, 2023", caption = "Christine Hou" ) + theme( plot.title = element_text(size=12), plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), legend.title = element_text(size=9), legend.text = element_text(size=8), axis.title = element_text(size = 9), axis.text = element_text(size = 8, angle = 45, hjust =1) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](data_analysis_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672 height=100%} ::: ::: Generally, Hispanic/Latin/Mexican (H), White (W), Asian (A), and Black (B) people are main victims. 4. Victim Time ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vic_time = data %>% mutate(Date.Rptd = mdy(sub("(\\d{2}/\\d{2}/\\d{4}).*", "\\1", Date.Rptd))) %>% mutate(Month = month(Date.Rptd), Year = year(Date.Rptd)) %>% arrange(Date.Rptd) %>% select(Crm.Cd,Month, Year) %>% group_by(Year, Month) %>% summarise(cases = n()) %>% pivot_wider(names_from = Year, values_from = cases) head(vic_time) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 5 Month `2020` `2021` `2022` `2023` 1 1 16060 16154 18397 20057 2 2 16490 15411 17710 18761 3 3 15539 16306 19801 19369 4 4 15178 16015 19769 19019 5 5 16331 16785 20597 19409 6 6 16955 17124 20263 18938 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} colors= c("2020" = "#e06666", "2021" = "#f6b26b", "2022" = "#93c47d","2023" = "#8e7cc3") vic_time %>% ggplot(aes(x = Month)) + geom_line(aes(y = `2020`, color = "2020")) + geom_line(aes(y = `2021`, color = "2021")) + geom_line(aes(y = `2022`, color = "2022")) + geom_line(aes(y = `2023`, color = "2023")) + scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:12, labels = as.character(1:12)) + scale_color_manual(values = colors) + theme_classic() + labs( x = "Month of Crime Report", y = "Number of Cases", title = "Victim Time of the Crime in the City of Los Angeles", subtitle = "Febraury 10, 2020 - November 1, 2023", caption = "Christine Hou", color = "Year" ) + theme( plot.title = element_text(size=12), plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), legend.title = element_text(size=9), legend.text = element_text(size=8), axis.title = element_text(size = 9), axis.text = element_text(size = 8) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](data_analysis_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Generally, the most frequent average crime happens after June. The first half of each year has less criminal cases than the second half of each year. ### Conclusions Based on the analysis on the dataset providing criminal information in the City of Los Angeles collected by LAPD, we obtain many useful conclusions. Since Febraury 10, 2020 which is the start time of data update, the criminal cases in the City of Los Angeles is gradually increasing, even though there were some small decrease during the period. I paid more attention on how the criminal cases are related to victims' gender, age, and race. In general, 1) The number of male victims was more than that of female victims; 2) Younger people (0-40 years old) were more likely to be attacked; 3) Hispanic/Latin/Mexican (H), White (W), Asian (A), and Black (B) people were main victims. 4) Many criminal cases tended to happen in the second six months from 2020 to 2023. ### Functions Used 1. `dplyr` - filter() - select() - summarize() - mutate() - arrange() - group_by() - case_when() 2. `tidyr` - pivot_wider() 3. `ggplot2` - ggplot() - geom_line() - geom_point() - geom_smooth() - geom_boxplot() - facet_wrap() - scale_x_continuous() - scale_color_manual() - labs() - theme() - theme_classic()
